headline.main: POLITICS IN KANSAS.; From our Special Correspondent. Rumors and Reports--Prospects of Gov. Walker--The Ultraists of Both Sides, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kansas is Low suffering from an attack of rumors and threats--a dreadful complication of disorder. The crisis occurs in October, and fears are expressed that the patient will be seized with another fit of convulsions before we can look for a perfect recovery.
docs.snippet: Kansas is Low suffering from an attack of rumors and threats--a dreadful complication of disorder. The crisis occurs in October, and fears are expressed that the patient will be seized with another fit of convulsions before we can look for a perfect...

docs.lead_paragraph: A LONG TERM.--A convict was discharged from sing sing prison on the 5th inst., who had spent thirty years in the State prison, He was sent to the old City prison in 1823, for the term of fourteen years. He was one of a chain-gang sent to Sing Sing in 1828, to build that prison. At the expiration of his term he was out about three years, then sent back for ten years.

docs.lead_paragraph: FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--A heart rending accident occurred yesterday afternoon at Peekskill. A gentleman named THOMAS SEWELL, a retired merchant of Baltimore,in attempting to get into the cars at Peekskill, while the cars were moving, fell upon the track, and, before the train could be stopped, three cars had passed over his body.

docs.lead_paragraph: The America arrived at Halifax yesterday, from Liverpool on the 15th, brings bad news from the Atlantic Telegraph Expedition, The Cable parted from the Niagara on the afternoon of Tuesday, 11th in consequence of a sudden check while in process of paying out.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Commissioners of Health, held at the City Library Room, yesterday, (Wednesday,) at 12 1/2 O'clock : Present, President PHILLIPS and CLANOY, Commissioners MILLER, THOMPSON, MORTON and ROCKWELL; WALTER F. CONOKLIN, Clerk. The following business was transacted: COMMUNICATION FROM THE CITY INSPECTOR.

docs.lead_paragraph: BY THE CITY OF WASHINGTON. THE AMERICAN HORSES IN ENGLAND-PRIOREARS AGAIN BEATEN,-The London News has a dispatch from the Lewes Races, announcing the defeat of Priorese, the American horse. The race was for the sussex County cup. The following is the summary of the race: The Sussex County cup, Value 200 sovereigns, by subscriptions of 10 soverigns, each with 50 added;

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; TEERS. FIRST REGIMENT NEW-YORK VOLUN THE BRITISH ENLISTMENTS Anniversary of the Capture of Mexico--Presentation of the Gold Snuff Bex--Considerable Talking and some Swearing. FOUND, ONE MORE GARROTER. THE ASSAULT ON MR. BRAINARD. A MOTHER DROWNED HERSELF. TURNERS. Pawnbrokers, Jank-Dealers and Organ-Grinders. YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.

docs.lead_paragraph: A meeting of the First Regiment New-York Volunteers was held last evening at the Mercer street House, their headquarters. The object of the meeting, as specified in the call, was to make arrangements for the reception of the Peensylvania Volunteers, who intend visiting this City on the 14th of next month, to unite with the New-York Volunteers in celebrating the Tenth Anniversary of the Capture of the City of Mexico.

headline.main: Condition of the City Prison---Reply to the Structures of Rev. Mr. Speur.; To the Editor of the New-york Daily Times:

docs.lead_paragraph: SIR: In the letter of "Rev." C. SPEAR, of "Brooklyn and Boston," in your issue of to-day, in reference to the City Prison, are a number of In-accuracies, the result either of insufficient observation or information, or a total misunderstanding of the character and purposes of the institution. These purposes are not "reformatory," The City Prison is a place simply of detention for suspected persons awaiting trial, for witnesses,

headline.main: AGRICULTURAL.; The Brendetuffs, Provisions and other Produce Markets--General Agricultural Intelligence.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since our last report the weather nas oeen the for pushing herd grass and most crops, there being little rain, but generally cloudy. More sunshine would have benefited the growing Corn. The harvesting, now about over, has been comparatively little interrupted by storms, and Wheat has been gathered in better condition than usual.
